<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate how the use of a lid affects the rate of cooling of water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 576, 138]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 147, 895, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 362, 532, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 144, 412]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 394, 529, 412]]<|/det|> • Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 410, 589, 427]]<|/det|> • Place the thermometer in the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 425, 918, 458]]<|/det|> • In Table 1.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0s\) and immediately start the stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 456, 918, 489]]<|/det|> • Record, in the table, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30s,\) 60s, 90s, 120s, 150s and 180s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 486, 548, 504]]<|/det|> • Remove the thermometer from the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 504]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 517, <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 533, 920, 566]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure in **(a)** for beaker \(\mathbf{B}\), using \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water, and replace the lid immediately after pouring in the water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 578]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 180, 599]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 580, 665, 599]]<|/det|> Complete the headings and the time column in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 610, 539, 628]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 670, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a circuit containing resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 410, 106]]<|/det|>
The circuit has been set up for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 576, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 144, 697, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 434, 532, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 144, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 465, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected so that it measures the potential difference across resistor \(\mathbf{X}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 478, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 510, 675, 530]]<|/det|>
Switch on. Record the value of the current \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\) in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 540, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
<form>\(I_{\mathrm{S}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 573, 181, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 573, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
• Use the voltmeter to measure and record the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{X}}\) across resistor \(\mathbf{X}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 618, 917, 640]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{\mathrm{X}} =\) ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 650, 405, 669]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 681, 920, 715]]<|/det|>
• Reconnect the voltmeter to measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{Y}}\) across resistor \(\mathbf{Y}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 727, 918, 747]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{\mathrm{Y}} =\) ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 744, 920, 763]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 775, 405, 793]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 805, 180, 824]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 805, 920, 840]]<|/det|>
Reconnect the voltmeter to measure and record the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{S}}\) across the combination of both resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 852, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
<form>\(V_{\mathrm{S}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 883, 282, 901]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 591, 91]]<|/det|>
The circuit components are to be rearranged so that:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 455, 121]]<|/det|>
• resistors \(\mathbf{X}\) and \(\mathbf{Y}\) are in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 650, 137]]<|/det|>
• the ammeter will measure the total current in the circuit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 784, 152]]<|/det|>
• the voltmeter will measure the potential difference across both resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 843, 183]]<|/det|>
In the space below, draw a diagram of this circuit using standard electrical symbols.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 144, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 460, 460]]<|/det|>
Set up the circuit as described in (d).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 920, 507]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 645, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 128, 897, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 373, 532, 392]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 144, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 405, 180, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 405, 880, 420]]<|/det|> • Move the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass to a distance \(d = 10.0\mathrm{cm}\) from the \(0.0\mathrm{cm}\) end of the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 420, 905, 437]]<|/det|> • Adjust the height of the clamp holding the forcemeter so that the rule is horizontal. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 435, 698, 452]]<|/det|> • Read, and record in Table 3.1, the forcemeter reading \(F.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 450, 883, 467]]<|/det|> • Repeat this procedure for values of \(d = 30.0 \text{cm}, 50.0 \text{cm}, 70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 481, 541, 498]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 507, 621, 662]]<|/det|>
\(d/\text {cm}\)\(F/\text {N}\)
10.0
30.0
50.0
70.0
90.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 666]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 679, 180, 696]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 679, 828, 696]]<|/det|> Explain how you made sure that the rule was horizontal before each reading. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 406, 712]]<|/det|> You may draw a diagram. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 851, 920, 870]]<|/det|>
........................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 883, 920, 902]]<|/det|> ........................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 911, 920, 929]]<|/det|> ........................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[876, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 571, 89]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(F / \mathsf{N}\) ( \(y\) -axis) against \(d / \mathsf{cm}\) ( \(x\) -axis).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 457, 104]]<|/det|>
Start your axes from the origin (0,0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 317, 134]]<|/det|>
Draw a best-fit line.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 144, 744, 556]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|>

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 622, 180, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 622, 719, 641]]<|/det|>
From your graph, determine \(F_{\mathrm{0}}\), the value of \(F\) when \(d = 0.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 651, 920, 672]]<|/det|>
<form>F_0  ......................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 685, 181, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 685, 809, 702]]<|/det|>
Calculate the weight \(W_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule, using the equation \(W_{\mathrm{R}} = 2 \times F_{\mathrm{0}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 698, 774, 717]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 761, 920, 780]]<|/det|>
<form>W_{\mathrm{R}} = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 767, 90]]<|/det|>
A student correctly plots your data points on another sheet of graph paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 771, 120]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether his best-fit line is likely to be the same as yours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 541, 136]]<|/det|>
Justify your answer with reference to the plots.

statement ...................................................................................................................................

explanation ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
Another student, carrying out the same experiment, is not sure if some of his values of \(F\) are correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
Suggest one improvement to the procedure which would help him to obtain more reliable \(F\) values.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 458, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 776, 89]]<|/det|>
A student has a box of converging lenses, but does not know their focal lengths.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment that will enable her to determine an accurate value for the focal length \(f\) of one of the lenses, using the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 144, 544, 173]]<|/det|>
\[f = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
where \(u\) is the distance between an object and the lens and \(v\) is the distance between the lens and the focused image of the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 398, 244]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 259, 267, 274]]<|/det|>
a lens holder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 520, 291]]<|/det|>
a 12 V lamp in a holder, with a power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 615, 306]]<|/det|>
a card with a triangular hole covered with tracing paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 378, 336]]<|/det|>
Write a plan for the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 220, 367]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 495, 399]]<|/det|>
list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 868, 429]]<|/det|>
draw a diagram of how the apparatus would be arranged, clearly labelling \(u\) and \(v\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 881, 461]]<|/det|>
write a method for carrying out the experiment including how \(f\) would be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 824, 492]]<|/det|>
state the precautions which should be taken to obtain a clear, focused image

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 505, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
state the precautions which should be taken to ensure that measurements are accurate once a focused image has been obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 522, 568]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 42, 512, 60]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>
